title: PCT 39 : A bony spectre abducts a woman
author: Adam Sakewew

sentences.english: A certain Cree had a younger brother, a mere youth.
The elder brother had one son.
This little boy fell very sick.
The man sought medical aid, employing people to use their power.

sentences.original: mâskôc awa kâ-sâkihak nikosis kita-nipiw, itêyihtam.
sentences.english: “Perhaps my beloved son is to die,” he thought.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê aw ôskinîkiw, ostêsah ê-sêkisiyit, mahtih, nistêsê, wâpatonisk miyin, itêw ostêsa.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê awa oskinîkiw ostêsa ê-sêkisiyit itêw ostêsa
sentences.english: Then at one time that youth whose brother was in fear, said to him, “Come, Brother, give me some white paint-clay.”
He gave him some.
Then he put the white clay all over his body.

sentences.original: âta êh-âhkosiyit okosisiwâwa, otinêw, ê-wayawîhtahât aw oskinîkiw.
sentences.text: âta ê-âhkosiyit okosisiwâwa otinêw ê-wayawîhtahât awa oskinîkiw
sentences.english: Although their son was ill, the youth took him up, and carried him out of the tent.
sentences.footnote: LB:  “Their son”: father's brother and mother's sister use the terms, “my son” and “my daughter” more often than the specific {nikosim}, {nitôsim}; the distinction between these is unknown to me; Lacombe's statement (Dict. 669f.) is confused.

sentences.english: When he brought the child in again, he was well.

sentences.original: êkosi kîtahtawê wîwiw; tâpiskôc wîwiwak ostêsa.
sentences.text: êkosi kîtahtawê wîwiw tâpiskôc wîwiwak ostêsa
sentences.english: Then, in the course of time, he took a wife; he took his wife from the same family as had his elder brother.
sentences.footnote: LB:  Literally, “they had wives in the same way”; the interpretation in the text is a surmise.

sentences.original: hâw, nisîm, atâwâkanak nôcihâtân; paskêpicitân, itêw osîma.
sentences.english: “Come, Younger Brother, let us go in pursuit of furs; let us move camp away from the band,” he said to his younger brother.
“Yes,” the latter answered him.

sentences.original: âsay otawâsimisiwak aw ôskinîkiw; misikitiyiwa, êh-pimitâcimoyit.
sentences.text: âsay otawâsimisiwak awa oskinîkiw misikitiyiwa ê-pimitâcimoyit
sentences.english: The youth and his wife had by this time a child; it was of a size to be crawling about.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê êh-mâcîcik, êkwah awa iskwêw nikohtêw.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê ê-mâcîcik êkwa awa iskwêw nikohtêw
sentences.english: Then at one time, as they were hunting, that woman gathered wood.
Then, at one time, she was missed.
She did not come home.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê êh-tipiskâyik, êkâ êh-takosihk, ntonikêwak ostêsah.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê ê-tipiskâyik êkâ ê-takosihk nitonikêwak ostêsa
sentences.english: Presently, as darkness fell and she did not arrive, the youth and his brother searched.
They did not find her; they did not come upon her tracks.
“Perhaps she suddenly died,” they thought.
Then he offered his elder brother a lighted pipe.
“My, elder brother, try to know about your sister-in-law.
Our son is crying much,” he told him.
“Very well,” the other answered him.
He sang.

sentences.original: nisîm, ôtah ômêskanaw awa nîtim pikoh niwâpahtên, êkotah oma kâ-ntonikêyahk.
sentences.english: “My younger brother, here I see only the path of my sister-in-law, even there where we made search.

sentences.original: namoya nântaw ntisi-wâpahtên ta-misi-wanâtisit awa nîtim ka-wanihâyahk.
sentences.english: Not in any way do I see that my sister-in-law whom we have lost has gone to her ruin.”
The elder brother filled a pipe.
He gave the other the pipe.
“My younger brother, smoke this.
Try to find my sister-in-law.
She has not been destroyed.
Perhaps you have some mystic power,” he said to his younger brother.
Then the youth smoked.
He took off his clothes.
Then he went to where his wife had gathered wood.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-pipohk; omayikohk ositah kaskitênam; êkwah ôhi ocihciyah kaskitênam aw ôskinîkiw.
sentences.text: êkwa ê-pipohk ômayikohk osita kaskitênam êkwa ôhi ocihciya kaskitênam awa oskinîkiw
sentences.english: It was winter; he blackened his feet, here; and he blackened his hands, the youth.

sentences.original: êkwah itohtêw; êy-otihtahk owîkimâkanah itah ê-kîh-nikohtêyit, ntonikêw.
sentences.text: êkwa itohtêw ê-otihtahk owîkimâkana ita ê-kî-nikohtêyit nitonikêw
sentences.english: Then he went there; when he came to where his wife had gathered firewood, he searched.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê kâ-wâpahtahk itah êh-kîh-nîpawiyit owîkimâkanah; itah ê-tahkoskêyit êkotah nîpaww.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê kâ-wâpahtahk ita ê-kî-nîpawiyit owîkimâkana ita ê-tahkoskêyit êkota nîpawiw
sentences.english: Presently he saw a place where his wife had stood; upon the imprints of her feet he placed his feet, as he stood.

sentences.original: itah êh-ayîtiskêyit, êkotah tahkoskêw aw oskinîkiw.
sentences.text: ita ê-ayîtiskêyit êkota tahkoskêw awa oskinîkiw
sentences.english: Upon the imprints of her feet, as she had gone, step after step, the youth placed his feet, as he walked.
He had a skin wrapped round him; but for this garment he was unclothed.
Then he made his steps wherever his wife had set foot.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê êkotah ohci êh-itâpit, pôt ôma tâpiskôc pîsimwêyâpiy isinâkwaniyiw ômêskanaw aw îskwêw, nayêwac ê-pimakocihk.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê êkota ohci ê-itâpit pôti ôma tâpiskôc pîsimwêyâpiy isinâkwaniyiw omêskanaw awa iskwêw nayêwac ê-pimakocihk
sentences.english: Presently, as he looked on ahead, lo, there, like a rainbow looked the trail of that woman, as she had left the ground and floated through the air.
The youth took off from the ground.
He floated through the air as though he were flying.

sentences.original: pôtih wâhyaw êh-ayât, pôtih minahikwâhtikwa êh-nawêyâskosiniyit, êkotah êsah kâh-nipâyit, namoya tâpwê êh-nipât, êh-owîcimosit anihi kâ-sipwêhtahikot.
sentences.text: pôti wâhyaw ê-ayât pôti minahikwâhtikwa ê-nawêyâskosiniyit êkota êsa kâ-nipâyit namôya tâpwê ê-nipât ê-owîcimosit anihi kâ-sipwêhtahikot
sentences.english: Behold, when he had gone a long ways, where a pine tree lay across the path, there she must have slept, - not that she had really slept, but where she had taken for her lover him who had abducted her.
From there she had again risen aloft.
He too rose aloft, gliding again through the air.
Presently she had again gone down to the ground.
He, too, at that point, went down to the ground.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê mohcihk êkwah ati-pimohtêyiwa, ê-sêskisiyit minahikoskâhk.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê mohcihk êkwa ati-pimohtêyiwa ê-sêskisiyit minahikoskâhk
sentences.english: Then she had walked on, on the earth, and had gone into a wood of pines.
There he beheld a large and ugly tent of old leather rags.
He saw another and smaller one.
Then he entered.

sentences.original: pôt ôhi kîh-apiyiwa wêskwâhtêmihk; kotakah nâpêwah pimitakâm apiyiwa.
sentences.text: pôti ôhi kî-apiyiwa wêskwâhtêmihk kotaka nâpêwa pimitakâm apiyiwa
sentences.english: Lo, there they sat, opposite the doorway; another man sat across the lodge from them.
There sat his wife, sitting by the side of a bony spectre.

sentences.original: awa pimitakâm k-âpit, êwako tapâhtiskwêyiw kotak pâkahkos, êh-ostêsit awa pâkahkos kâ-kimotit iskwêwa.
sentences.text: awa pimitakâm kâ-apit êwako tapahtiskwêyiw kotak pâkahkos ê-ostêsit awa pâkahkos kâ-kimotit iskwêwa
sentences.english: That other bony spectre who sat aross the lodge, lowered his head; and he was the elder brother of him who had stolen the woman.

sentences.original: êkwah aw oskinîkiw pimohtêw, pâskisikan apasôhk êh-takopitêyik, ê-wâpihtakâyik;
sentences.text: êkwa awa oskinîkiw pimohtêw pâskisikan apasôhk ê-takopitêyik ê-wâpihtakâyik
sentences.english: Then that youth walked over to where a gun hung from the lodgepole; it looked like a bleached stick; he thought,

sentences.original: pâskisikan pôt ôma! wîsta nika-otinên oma pâskisikan; nîst âyako nik-âyân! itêyihtam.
sentences.english: “So this is a gun! From him, in turn, I shall take the gun; I, in turn, shall have it!”

sentences.original: êkwah êy-otinahk, pimakocin aw îskwêwa kâ-kimotit pâkahkos, êh-pâhpit.
sentences.text: êkwa ê-otinahk pimakocin awa iskwêwa kâ-kimotit pâkahkos ê-pâhpit
sentences.english: As he took it, that bony spectre who had stolen the woman, came reaching for it, with a peal of laughter.
“My follow-husband, let go of this my gun!
I love this gun of mine!
Take back our wife!” said the bony spectre.
“No! You took her, when I, too, loved her.
Now I will take a thing you love.
That is why I have come to take your gun.
When I loved her who is your wife, you came and took her.
So now I cannot have her to wife.”

sentences.original: â, nikosâk, kiyâm miyin nipâskisikan; mistahi nisâkihtân! itwêw awa pâkahkos.
sentences.english: “Oh, Fellow-Husband, please, give me my gun; I prize it too highly!” cried the bony spectre.
“I shall not by any chance give it to you.”
“If you wish, never will you fail of any game.
You will be good at killing every kind of beast.
Always I shall go at your side.”
“No!” said the youth.

sentences.original: êkwah aw ôstêsimâw wayawîw, ohtâwiya êh-ntawi-ntomât.
sentences.text: êkwa awa ostêsimâw wayawîw ôhtâwiya ê-nitawi-nitomât
sentences.english: Then that elder one went out of the tent to call his father.
The old man Koshtchey entered.
“Alas, my children have stood facing each other!
sentences.footnote: LB:  Literally, “they have stood in relation to each other, by each other”, but the actual meaning is unknown to me.

sentences.original: âta nôton, nikîh-itâw awa nkosis; nikîh-itâw mâna, wiyîhtamôwaki kêkway, ahci piko kâ-tôtahk, kâ-kacâc êh-onâpêmiyit kâ-maskâhtwât awa nikâkêpâtisîm, êkâ êh-tâpwêhtawit.
sentences.english: Although often, 'Do not take a woman of the common, mortal men,' I said to my son; 'Of manitou nature are real men,' though I told him more than once, when I instructed him, yet none the less he did so, robbing, as if none other would serve, one who had a husband, this stubborn fool of mine, who does not heed my words.

sentences.original: - nkosis, êkos âwa êh-tâpwêt, awa kikosâk kây-isi-wîhtamâsk.
sentences.english: - My  son, even thus he speaks true, this thy fellow-husband, in what he has told thee.
All night we will teach thee songs and how to do.
Pray, hear me with pity.
We greatly prize our guns.
This one here, your kinsman now, obeys my word;
sentences.footnote: LB on {kiciwâm}:  Thus it appears that {niciwâm}: “my brother (man speaking(” has, among its many uses that of “my fellow-husband's brother.”

sentences.original: tânisi êh-itak tôtam, awa kikosâk ê-kakêpâtisit, kâ-ntawi-kimotamâsk kiwîkimâkanah.
sentences.english: as I tell him, he does, while he, your fellow-husband is foolish and stubborn, and thus has gone and stolen your wife from you.
But in this he spoke true which he told you.”
“Very well.
Do not speak false.

sentences.original: awa nka-kîwêhtahâw kîwinaw, itwêw aw ôskinîkiw.
sentences.english: I shall take home with me this wife of ours,” said the youth.
“So be it.”

sentences.original: pêyakotipiskwa pikoh ôtah nik-âyânân; wâpahki nka-kîwânân awa kistim.
sentences.english: “One night only we shall stay here; tomorrow your daughter-in-law here and I shall go home.”
sentences.footnote: LB on {pêyakotipiskwa}:  Not to be divided by hyphen; {-tipiskwa} (particle) and {-tipiskwê-} (verb) are the non-initial (suffixal) forms corresponding to {tipisk} and {tipiskwâw}.  Similarly, {kîsikâw}: “it is day” has the odd non-initial verb-forming suffix {-kîsihkwê-}.

sentences.english: “There, Kinsman, I thank you for having lent ear to him who is now your father as well as ours.
Because you have done me this favor, never shall mortal man be lost to you.

sentences.original: iyâhkosicih, kika-pmâcihâw; ahpôh awâsis, iskwêw, nama wîhkâc ka-kîhikon kita-pimâcihat.
sentences.english: Whenever one is sick,  you shall restore him to life; be it a child, a woman, never shall he  be beyond your power of restoring him to life.
There, brother, this is my gift to you.

sentences.original: kikosâk minahôwin kiwîhtamâk, ta-wahkêh-nipahtâyan kêkway pisiskiwak.
sentences.english: Your fellow-husband promised you the killing of game, of every kind of beast.”
Thus he spoke to him.

sentences.original: êkwah niya, nkosis, mahtâhitôwin kik-êsiyîhkâtên; êwako niya kimiyitin.
sentences.english: “And I, my son, Potlatch you will call it; this is what I give to you.
Give me fat to eat, when you arrive at your home.

sentences.original: êkotah cîkih kâ-wîkiyêk nîso môswak kimiyitin, kit-âsamiyin, êkotah ohci pimiy kit-ôtinaman.
sentences.english: Close by to where you dwell, two moose I give you, that you may feed me, that you may take the fat from them.

sentences.original: êkosi awa kiciwâm k-êtwêt, êkosi nîsta kitisi-miyitin.
sentences.english: And even as your brother said, even such a gift I too am giving you.”
“So be it,” he said.
Then his fellow-husband taught him songs.
At last day dawned.

sentences.original: ê-kîsi-nikamohikot, êh-wâpaniyik, wayawîwak owîkimâkanah aw oskinîkiw.
sentences.text: ê-kîsi-nikamohikot ê-wâpaniyik wayawîwak owîkimâkana awa oskinîkiw
sentences.english: When he had been taught the songs, and day had come, the youth and his wife went from that tent.
The bony spectre, too, went out, to escort his fellow-husband.

sentences.original: hâw, nikosâk, êkâya kotakah nâpêwah kit-âyâwêw kîwinaw.
sentences.english: “Very well, Fellow-Husband; let not our wife have dealings with other men.
I give you a full span of life.
And our son, too, shall live a full span of life.

sentences.original: tâpwê êkâ wiya wîhkâc kita-mâmawîhitôw kîwinaw; nkâhkwêyihtaskin.
sentences.english: But see to it that our wife never be guilty of adultery; I am jealous in marriage.”
So he and his wife went home.
They reached their dwelling.
That same day the youth hunted.
He killed two fat moose;

sentences.original: kahkiyaw otinam pimiyah oskanihk ohci, êkwah êwako êh-asamât ohtâwiya, ociwâma, okosâka.
sentences.text: kahkiyaw otinam pimiya oskanihk ohci êkwa êwako ê-asamât ôhtâwiya ociwâma okosâka
sentences.english: he took all the marrow from the bones, and made of it an offering to his adoptive father and brother and to his fellow-husband.

sentences.original: êkwah aspin êy-ispayik namoy âcimôw aw ôskinîkiw.
sentences.text: êkwa aspin ê-ispayik namôya âcimôw awa oskinîkiw
sentences.english: And the youth did not tell of what had happened from the time he went away.
That man did not question his younger brother.

sentences.original: tânis êtokê tiyôtahk awa nisîm, kâ-pêsiwât owîkimâkanah!
sentences.english: “I wonder how my younger brother did, to bring back his wife!

sentences.original: kêhcinâ mantôww awa nisîm! itêyihtam aw ostêsimâw.
sentences.english: Surely my younger brother has manitou power!” thought the elder brother.

sentences.original: êkwah ôhô okosisiwâwa tân-tahtw askiy êh-wih-ohpikiyit, kîtahtawê êh-kwâpikêt aw îskwêw, kotakah nâpêwa kâ-kitotât, êh-mamawîhtot.
sentences.text: êkwa ôho okosisiwâwa tânitahto askiy ê-wî-ohpikiyit kîtahtawê ê-kwâpikêt awa iskwêw kotaka nâpêwa kâ-kitotât ê-mâmawîhitot
sentences.english: Then when that son of theirs, after I know not how many years, was nearly grown, then at one time, when that woman was fetching water, she had converse with another man, and committed adultery.
As she went home, someone struck her on the shoulder.
Then at once she became ill.

sentences.original: mayaw êh-âhkosiyit, awa nâpêw atoskêmôw, ta-nânapâcihimiht owîkimâkanah.
sentences.text: mayaw ê-âhkosiyit awa nâpêw atoskêmôw ta-nânapâcihimiht owîkimâkana
sentences.english: As soon as she fell sick, that man called in doctors, that his wife might have treatment.
In this way he learned that his wife had been struck.
He questioned her.
“I had been having a talk with that young man.

sentences.original: êkosi êh-pê-kîwêyân, êkotah kâ-pasastêwokawiyân ntihtimanihk; êwak ohci k-âhkosiyân.
sentences.english: Then, as I was coming home, I was struck with a stick or switch on my shoulder; from that I am sick.”

sentences.original: piyisk kêkâc nipiw aw îskwêw mihcêtwayak êh-atoskêmohk.
sentences.text: piyisk kêkâc nipiw awa iskwêw mihcêtwayak ê-atoskêmohk
sentences.english: At last that woman was close to death, though many kinds of doctoring were tried.

sentences.original: piyisk awa aw ôskinîkiw kâ-wîwit ostêsah miyik ospwâkanah, kita-pîhtwât.
sentences.text: piyisk awa awa oskinîkiw kâ-wîwit ostêsa miyik ospwâkana kita-pîhtwât
sentences.english: At last the youth whose wife she was, was given a pipe by his elder brother, that he smoke.
“Try to treat my sister-in-law, Younger Brother.
All kinds of treatment have already been given her.”

sentences.original: hâw, ôma kâ-sakâk êkotah osîhtâk têsipicikan, itwêw aw oskinîkiw.
sentences.english: “Very well, over in that grove set up a scaffold,” said the youth.
Accordingly a scaffold was built for him.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-tipiskâyik, êkotê itohtahâw aw îskwêw k-âhkosit.
sentences.text: êkwa ê-tipiskâyik êkotê itohtahâw awa iskwêw kâ-âhkosit
sentences.english: Then, at nightfall, the sick woman was taken there.

sentences.original: êh-kîwêcik, namwâc cêskwah otihtam awa wîkiwâw, awa oskinîkiw, awa mîna ostêsimâw, âsay itah wîtimwah k-âkociniyit, êkotah âsay kâ-matwêwêyit, ê-sâkowêwiht.
sentences.text: ê-kîwêcik namwâc cêskwa otihtam awa wîkiwâw awa oskinîkiw awa mîna ostêsimâw âsay ita wîtimwa kâ-akociniyit êkota âsay kâ-matwêwêyik ê-sâkowêwiht
sentences.english: When they went back home, that youth with his elder brother had not yet reached their dwelling-place, when already, from where the latter's sister-in-law lay high on the scaffold, there came the report of a gun, and they heard shouting.
sentences.footnote: LB on {kâ-matwêwêyit}:  If correctly recorded, an animate form, my impression is, however, that {-wêwê-}: “noise” forms only inanimate verbs; if so, we should read {matwêwêyik}.

sentences.original: nikosâk, kîwinaw pê-nâs; âsay pimâtisiw, itâw.
sentences.english: “My fellow-husband, come get our wife; already she is cured,” he was told.
The youth went back there.

sentences.original: kahkiyaw pêhtawâw awa pâkahkos tânisi êh-itwêt.
sentences.text: kahkiyaw pêhtawâw awa pâkahkos tânisi ê-itwêt
sentences.english: Everything was heard which that bony spectre said.
When he reached his wife, she was already climbing down.
He took her home.

sentences.original: êh-takohtêt wîkiwâhk, âsay miyw-ayâw aw îskwêw, mistahi ka-kîh-âhkosit.
sentences.text: ê-takohtêt wîkiwâhk âsay miyo-ayâw awa iskwêw mistahi kâ-kî-âhkosit
sentences.english: When she reached their dwelling, she was already well, sick as she had been.

sentences.original: êkosi êkotah ohcih kiskêyimâw aw ôskinîkiw êh-mamâhtâwisit.
sentences.text: êkosi êkota ohci kiskêyimâw awa oskinîkiw ê-mamâhtâwisit
sentences.english: So then from this the youth was known to have magic powers.
Thus this woman was restored to life.
And then that youth arranged a potlatch ceremony.
And then he was feared, because he was thought to have spirit power.
And his wife was not wooed by any man.
And from this it came that the Cree have the potlatch.
Here ends the story.
